item.title: No Man's Sky adds ship wreck salvaging for new bits to stick on your own craft with the Breach update
item.content:encoded:
Get your zero-g coat, it's time for a space walk

If the interstellar equivalent of scrabbling around under the sofa for loose change or dragging a slightly rusty bumper out of a scrapyard is something you yearn for, No Man's Sky's latest update sounds right up your slightly grimy alley. It's dubbed Breach and adds in a bunch of mysterious shipwrecks to strip for new parts you can then glue to your own vessel. High stakes recycling, basically.

"In Breach, players will traverse a desolate and abandoned universe and on their travels encounter the abandoned remains of ill-fated corvette ships, all ripe for scavenging ship modules to add to your corvette-building arsenal, read the update's notes. "Excavating these wrecks will yield an array of corvette pieces including rare vertical parts which unlock a whole new range of build configurations for the more creative designers." Some Atlas-themed bits are also out there for you to ping off with your laser and pocket.

As usual with these free updates to the space sim, there's a limited-time expedition to head out on. it looks to revolve around a the wreck of the Fireship Arcadia, with a trip to the edge of space and some general mysteriousness teased. "Many such wrecks have begun to appear throughout the far reaches of space, and there are rewards for the bravest of Travellers prepared to scavenge from them, including new vertical and structural parts which allow players to build colossal ships and rare, glowing Atlas-themed wings, engines and features," the notes say.

For those keen to know exactly what sorts of extra ship bits have been added in as par of this broadening of ship building horizons, Hello Games list landing gear, shields, weapons, and connectors, plus some "highly-requested wedge-shaped modules" so people can get a bit artsy with their builds. I assume by making ships shaped like wedges of cheese. They'd better add in moons made of cheese next, so I can do the dairy double and make Wallace of 'and Gromit' fame proud.

No Man's Sky's Breach update is out now. We've got you covered if you're thinking of hopping in for the first time in a while and so need quick refreshers as to what the long-running space explorer's last couple of updates have included.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/no-mans-sky-adds-ship-wreck-salvaging-for-new-bits-to-stick-on-your-own-craft-with-the-breach-update

item.title: The Lord of the Rings: Return to Moria's first expansion launches next month, even if gameplay is currently MIA
item.content:encoded:
I hope they're not folking around

It's been more than a year since The Lord of the Rings: Return to Moria first launched, and now it seems like the survival crafting game's first proper expansion is right around the corner. Developer Free Range Games shared a new trailer yesterday, which was roughly Durin's Day, a rare Dwarven event in the world of Middle-earth, appropriately revealing the release date for said expansion, Durin's Folk.

It's less than a month out in fact, due to be released this coming November 18th, and while there are some details already available for the DLC, there's one slightly odd thing about it: there's no gameplay. There have been a couple of blog posts, and even a podcasty thing all about it, the posts complete with screenshots, but there doesn't appear to be a lick of footage of the thing in motion. Perhaps a point to be concerned about when there's so little time until it arrives; I wouldn't be surprised if it's just not quite ready to be properly shown and the folks at the top of the food chain want a date out to meet some kind of internal target, but that's just conjecture.

Still, those details! On the story side of things, you'll be learning about Dwarves from the Fourth Age, and a new end-game story chapter will be there for you to play through. There'll also be NPCs you can rescue and recruit down in the mines, of whom will help you out in your settlement, becoming typically dwarvey things like blacksmiths and brewmasters.

There's some new procedurally generated dungeons to presumably mine and plunder, which can be done alone or in multiplayer. The expansion also lets you explore outside the mountain too, including Durin's Tower, and an area to build some big bases. Lastly, the end-game economy is getting an update, offering up new materials, items, and recipes to unlock lore and other bits.

Presumably at some point in the next few weeks a proper trailer will be shown off, but off not, I suppose you'll find out when The Lord of the Rings: Return to Moria's Durin's Folk expansion launches on November 18th.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/the-lord-of-the-rings-return-to-morias-first-expansion-launches-next-month-even-if-gameplay-is-currently-mia
